references.paper_title: Understanding black-box predictions via influence functions
references.reason: This paper introduces the concept of influence functions for interpreting machine learning models, which is central to the current work on influential subset selection.

references.paper_title: An automatic finite-sample robustness metric: when can dropping a little data make a big difference?
references.reason: This paper proposes the ZAMinfluence algorithm, a greedy heuristic for most influential subset selection, which serves as a basis for the comparative analysis in this paper.

references.paper_title: Hidden in plain sight: Influential sets in linear models
references.reason: This paper introduces the adaptive greedy algorithm, a refinement of the influence-based greedy heuristics which is shown to address some of their limitations and is a key focus of the current work.

references.paper_title: An analysis of approximations for maximizing submodular set functions
references.reason: This seminal paper analyzes the approximability of submodular maximization problems, which provides theoretical guarantees for the adaptive greedy algorithm studied in this work.

references.paper_title: On second-order group influence functions for black-box predictions
references.reason: This paper extends the influence function approach to capture higher-order interactions among samples, which helps to address the limitations of additive influence-based methods.
